The British Empire is a great nation, which has for centuries taken the lead in civilization ; it cannot therefore be supposed that such a people can fail to do right when they undertake the civilizing of others. When we speak of the uncivilized states of Africa and Asia, we mean those peoples who are ignorant of the uses of letters and books, who know nothing of our modes of government, whose customs differ from ours in almost every particular, and who have no conception of law or justice as we understand them. In dealing with these peoples the British Government must act on its own principles. We must remember that our object is not to conquer, but to improve ; not to rob, but to enrich; not to corrupt, but to educate. The best way of doing this is by means of missionaries, commerce, and education. We have already established schools and hospitals at many places throughout the world where the natives are taught English and other useful branches of knowledge. It is our duty to extend these institutions, so that all the inhabitants of the colonies may benefit by their advantages. As regards commerce, we must not only encourage trade with our subjects, but also make it easy and profitable for us to deal with them. It would be very wrong if the natives were to be allowed to raise prices beyond what we could afford to pay ; we must keep them low. A wise government will always look out for its interests ; and it is evident that a proper system of taxation will soon make the natives wealthy enough

The British Empire has no moral obligation to any savage or semi-savage tribes ; they are not under her tutelage, but are free to live as their ancestors lived. The British Empire governs only those who are ready to be governed by her laws and institutions — i.e., those who wish it. The duty of civilization is not to be thrust upon the unwilling. This is a great error which has led many people to suppose that we should " teach the savages our ways." It was the duty of the old Romans to civilize the barbarians, and so on with all the ancient empires. But what does this prove? It proves that civilization in the sense of culture, art, refinement, etc., has nothing to do with the development of man in his higher spiritual aspects. It proves that when men have reached the stage of civilization (as defined), they will naturally and instinctively spread over the globe and subjugate all who fall into their power, and thus become the masters of the world. They may then, if they please, try to bring these lower races up to their own level, but they must not compel them to do so. In reality, they can never be brought up to their level unless they choose to accept the new mode of life. If they refuse, there is nothing left for the civilized nations but to allow them to pursue their former methods of living, to let them alone, and to leave them at peace in their native land.
